programme is designed for those with degree level subject
knowledge in Theology, Sociology, Psychology or Philosophy
and a good background in Religious Studies at school, who
wish to teach in secondary schools.
We have a long tradition of training RE teachers. We train
students from all faith backgrounds and have well-established
partnerships with schools in Yorkshire and across the Northeast
region, in both denominational and non-denominational schools.
The employment rate of our students is extremely high and
graduates have readily obtained teaching posts all over
the UK as well as within our partnership schools.
The first term is mainly campus-based and designed to develop
knowledge and understanding of the roles and practice of
a teacher. It covers the place of religious education in
the Secondary Curriculum and its relationship with cross-curricular
In order to teach pupils in the 11-18 age range, you will
gain a broad knowledge of world religions. During the programme,
you will also develop a repertoire of teaching strategies
for working with pupils in a variety of curriculum contexts:

column2: The legal and moral responsibilities of a teacher
Professional options: Catholic Education or Citizenship
Serial visits to the first training school to provide

column1: a gradual introduction to working in the classroom
During the second and third terms, you will follow a training
programme in two different partnership schools, during which
time you will have opportunities to:

column2: Teach pupils across the age and attainment range
Work with pupils in a variety of syllabus contexts
Work alongside form tutors and special needs co-ordinators
Participate in a range of whole-school activities

column1: including assemblies, retreats, school celebrations and
In order to be eligible for Qualified Teacher Status (QTS),
you must demonstrate your ability to meet the assessment
for Education and Skills/Teacher Training Agency (DfES/TTA).
by coursework assignments and by performance in classroom
teaching and training activities in schools.
Our new library and computer centre is well-stocked with
a range of classroom text books and other teaching resources,
education books, journals, audio-visual resources, CD-Rom
databases and video and production facilities.
Applications must be made through the Graduate
There is no closing date but you are encouraged to apply
early so that we can advise you about the appropriate preparation
you will need to make prior to starting the course, including
Write to: GTTR, Rosehill, New Barn Lane, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire
Find out more information about PGCE Funding
A degree in either Theology or Religious Studies
or a degree and educational background which has relevance
to teaching religious education in secondary schools
GCSE English and Mathematics at Grade C or above or equivalent
We offer our own internal Mathematics test to those who
have a conditional place on the course but who do not already
